newsitem.title: USA: Strong U.S. drug stocks recovery keyed by upgrade.
newsitem.headline: Strong U.S. drug stocks recovery keyed by upgrade.

text.p: Set in motion by a key investment rating upgrade, major U.S. drug stocks on Tuesday surged ahead of a broadly rising stock market.
After leading a downside plunge on Monday, blue-chip drug issues charged back in late Tuesday trading.

"What you're seeing in general in the group is a recovery from yesterday," said Merrill Lynch drug industry analyst Steve Tighe, whose upgrade of Bristol-Myers Squibb Co to long-term buy from long-term accumulate was credited by some traders as sparking the drug sector stampede.

Bristol-Myers shares were up 8-1/8 to 84-1/2. Among other top drug stocks, Pfizer Inc was up 5-1/4 to 116-1/4; Eli Lilly and Co was up 4-13/16 to 110-13/16; Merck & Co Inc was up 4-1/2 to 103-1/8; Warner-Lambert Co was up 4-7/16 to 119-9/16 -- price swings of a sort seldom seen in the sector.
"The drug stocks are acting like the tech stocks today," said Gruntal & Co drug industry analyst David Saks.

Institutional investors likely were pouring capital into Big Pharma, as the sector is known, ahead of anticipated strong second-quarter earnings reports and in line with general market bullishness on large-cap stocks, analysts said.
"Drug group fundamentals are exceptionally strong right now. It's the Dow stocks and the big index stocks that are doing well," said Alex. Brown drugs analyst Barbara Ryan.
"Coming into the end of the quarter, if people don't own them, they're going to look a little silly ... Some of this is a little bit of window-dressing for the end of the quarter," Ryan said.

The move marked a sharp reversal from Monday, when drug issues were among the hardest hit in a blue chip sell-off that saw the Dow Jones industrial average post its biggest percentage-point decline in almost a year.
"Some of this is a rebound off yesterday's decline," said drugs analyst Samuel Isaly, of Mehta & Isaly.
